org.commonvox.collections

Class OrderedSet<V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractSet<E>
        • java.util.HashSet<V>
          • org.commonvox.collections.OrderedSet<V>
  • Type Parameters:
    V - The valueClass, i.e. the class of objects contained and ordered by this OrderedSet.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Cloneable, Iterable<V>, Collection<V>, Set<V>

    public class OrderedSet<V>
extends HashSet<V>
    An OrderedSet provides composite-key based ordering of a set of values (analogous to composite key ordering in a relational database). Its unique advantage (over standard ordering/sorting options such as TreeSet, SortedSet, or Collections#sort) is in automatic ordering based on collection-attributes, such as in a Book class that has an authors (set of Author objects) attribute and a genres (set of Genre objects) attribute, which could be ordered via a Genre|Author|Title composite-key. The full results of ordering are provided by the OrderedSet#entrySet method which returns ordered entries, each consisting of a composite-key mapped to the its corresponding value.

    Usage examples can be found here.

    The components of an OrderedSet's composite-key structure are stipulated via an array of KeyComponentProfile objects submitted to the OrderedSet constructor. Continuing with the example above, to create an OrderedSet for ordering a set of Book values via an Author|Title composite-key, the following constructor invocation could be used: 
    
  OrderedSet<Book> booksOrderedByAuthorAndTitle =
    new OrderedSet<Book>(
      new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Author.class),   // 1st component is Author.
      new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Title.class));   // 2nd component is Title.
          // 3rd component is Book (automatically added to assure composite-key uniqueness).
    Note that a KeyComponentProfile based upon the valueClass itself (in the example case, Book) is always automatically appended as the final component in any specified KeyComponentProfile array, to assure uniqueness of composite-keys.

    Any Book objects added to the set above are immediately retrievable as a list in Author|Title|Book order via invocation of the values() method; given that a Book may have multiple Authors, a single Book may appear in the list multiple times (once for each of its Authors). Additionally, a list of the Books by a specific Author (in Title|Book order) is retrievable via submission of an Author object to the values(Object keyComponentObject) method. Note that use of one of the values methods is required to retrieve an ordered list of values. Iteration against the OrderedSet itself gives exactly the same result as would iteration against an equivalent HashSet populated with the same collection of objects.

    GO TO USAGE EXAMPLES

    CONSTRUCTION OF A KeyComponentProfile
    The first two (mandatory) parameters of the KeyComponentProfile constructor are (1) the valueClass (the class of objects contained in the OrderedSet to which the KeyComponentProfile belongs) and (2) the keyComponentClass (the class of objects to be automatically retrieved and ordered as a component of the composite-key). During construction of a KeyComponentProfile, Java reflection is used to find all valueClass-methods which return object(s) of the keyComponentClass (e.g., in the example above, #getTitle returns a Title.class object, and #getAuthors returns a collection of Author.class objects).

    AUTOMATIC RETRIEVAL AND ORDERING OF COMPOSITE-KEY COMPONENTS
    When a value is added to the OrderedSet, all of its related composite-key components (keyComponentClass-objects) are automatically retrieved and ordered. The end result is (in effect) a mapping of the composite-key to the value, or multiple mappings if multiple composite-keys are derived in the process (as in the example above when a Book contains multiple Author attribute objects). Internal retrieval of the keyComponentClass-objects is done via reflection-based invocation of the valueClass-methods identified during KeyComponentProfile construction. All retrieved keyComponentClass-objects are internally ordered via backing TreeMaps, either in natural order, hashCode order, or the order maintained by a specified Comparator. If a keyComponentClass implements the Comparable interface, its objects will be ordered in natural order; otherwise they will be ordered in hashCode order. However, if a KeyComponentProfile is constructed with specification of a Comparator, its related keyComponentClass-objects will be ordered by the Comparator.

    CONSTRUCTION OF A KeyComponentProfile WITH SPECIFIED GET METHOD(s)
    In some cases a given keyComponentClass may be returned by multiple valueClass-methods, but it is desired that only a subset of these methods should be the focus of a KeyComponentProfile. An optional vararg array of Method(s) may be submitted in the KeyComponentProfile constructor to specify such a subset. Continuing with the example above, if two methods of the Book class both return objects of the Date class (#getPublicationDate and #getRevisionPublicationDate), then an OrderedSet for ordering Books via a PublicationDate|Title|Book composite-key could be constructed as follows (limiting the focus of the first KeyComponentProfile to the #getPublicationDate method): 
    
  OrderedSet<Book> booksOrderedByPublicationDateAndTitle =
      new OrderedSet<>(
          new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Date.class,
                          Book.class.getDeclaredMethod("getPublicationDate")),
          new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Title.class));
    KeyComponentSets
    In addition to its ordered list of valueClass-elements, an OrderedSet automatically maintains a keyComponentSet corresponding to each KeyComponentProfile submitted via the OrderedSet constructor. A keyComponentSet is a unique set of all retrieved keyComponentClass-objects relating to a given KeyComponentProfile. Continuing with the example above, an OrderedSet of Book values constructed with a Genre|Author|Title composite-key would maintain three separate keyComponentSets: a complete unique set of all Genre objects found in the composite-key entries, a unique set of Author objects, and a unique set of Title objects. A keyComponentSet may be retrieved through invocation of the keyComponentSet(KeyComponentProfile) method. A keyComponentSet is a TreeSet, ordered either in natural order, hashCode order, or the order maintained by a specified Comparator. If the related keyComponentClass implements the Comparable interface, keyComponentClass-objects will be ordered in natural order; otherwise they will be ordered in hashCode order. However, if the corresponding KeyComponentProfile is constructed with specification of a Comparator, the keyComponentClass-objects will be ordered by the Comparator.

    Note that this implementation (which extends the HashSet class) is not synchronized. For more information/advice on potential concurrent usage of this class, please see the HashSet documentation.

    Special note on making modifications to a mutable object that is an element in an OrderedSet: Modifications made directly to an object that is an element in an OrderedSet can result in a disordering of the OrderedSet's internal mapping structures. Therefore, the following sequence must be followed when altering the fields of any mutable object that is an element in an OrderedSet:
    1. Remove the object from the OrderedSet.
    2. Make a deep-copy clone of the removed object.
    3. Make desired modifications to the object-clone.
    4. Add the object-clone to the OrderedSet.
     
    USAGE EXAMPLES
    The following examples show composite-key ordering of a set of objects of the Book.class, which has attributes of Author, Title, Genre, and Date classes returned by the methods Book#getAuthors(), Book#getTitle(), Book#getGenres(), Book#getPublicationDate() and Book#getRevisionPublicationDate().

    Example 1 orders Books by Author|Title; Example 2 orders Books by Genre|PublicationDate|Title (most recently published listed first). 
    
  //== EXAMPLE 1 ==//
  public void orderBooksByAuthorAndTitle() {

    //-- Construct and populate OrderedSet --//
    OrderedSet<Book> booksByAuthorAndTitle
            = new OrderedSet<>(
                    new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Author.class),
                    new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Book.Title.class));

    booksByAuthorAndTitle.addAll(getRandomOrderBookCollection());

    //-- Print results hierarchically --//
    System.out.println("\n========\nBooks ordered by AUTHOR and TITLE\n========");
    printHierarchically(booksByAuthorAndTitle);
  }

  //== EXAMPLE 2 ==//
  public void orderBooksByGenreNewestToOldest() throws NoSuchMethodException {

    //-- Construct KeyComponentProfiles (one w/ Comparator & specific get method specified) --//
    KeyComponentProfile<Book> genreKeyComponent
            = new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Genre.class);
    KeyComponentProfile<Book> publicationDateKeyComponent
            = new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Date.class,
                    (date1, date2) -> date2.compareTo(date1), // DESCENDING Date Comparator
                    Book.class.getDeclaredMethod("getPublicationDate")); // limit Date.class focus to THIS method!
    KeyComponentProfile<Book> titleKeyComponent
            = new KeyComponentProfile<>(Book.class, Book.Title.class);

    //-- Construct and populate OrderedSet --//
    OrderedSet<Book> booksByGenreAndPublicationDateAndTitle
            = new OrderedSet<>(getRandomOrderBookCollection(),
                    genreKeyComponent, publicationDateKeyComponent, titleKeyComponent);

    //-- Print results hierarchically --//
    System.out.println("\n========\nBooks by Genre, listed NEWEST to OLDEST\n========");
    printHierarchically(booksByGenreAndPublicationDateAndTitle);

    //-- Print all Genres in natural order --//
    System.out.println("==========\nGENRE list\n==========");
    for (Object genre : booksByGenreAndPublicationDateAndTitle.keyComponentSet(genreKeyComponent)) {
      System.out.println(genre);
    }
  }
    Complete Gist examples are available here.
    Author:
    Daniel Vimont

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      OrderedSet(Collection<? extends V> collection, KeyComponentProfile<V>... keyComponentProfiles)
      Constructs an OrderedSet containing the values in the specified collection, with the values ordered according to the composite-key specified in the submitted vararg array of KeyComponentProfile parameters.
      OrderedSet(KeyComponentProfile<V>... keyComponentProfiles)
      Constructs an empty OrderedSet configured for composite-key based ordering of its values as specified in the submitted vararg array of KeyComponentProfile parameters.

      • add

        public final boolean add(V value)
        Adds the specified value (i.e., object) to this OrderedSet if it is not already present, and orders the value via the composite-key stipulated by the keyComponentProfiles of the set. A null value is not accepted.
        Specified by:
        add in interface Collection<V>
        Specified by:

        Returns:
        true if this set did not already contain the specified element. The value may not be null.

      • remove

        public boolean remove(Object o)
        Removes the specified object from this set if it is present, and clears any corresponding composite-key entries. Note that invocation of this method will result in a rebuilding of internal keyComponentSets.

      • compositeKeys

        public final Set<List<Object>> compositeKeys()
        Returns a Set of the composite-keys in this OrderedSet. Each composite-key is in the format of a List of the keyComponentClass-objects of which it is comprised. This Set of composite-keys matches the key portion of the entries returned by the entrySet() method.
        Returns:
        Set consisting of keyComponentClass-object Lists.

      • entrySet

        public final Set<Map.Entry<List<Object>,V>> entrySet()
        The composite-key-ordered entries of this OrderedSet, with composite-key instances structured and ordered according to the array of KeyComponentProfiles with which the OrderedSet was constructed. Each entry pairs a composite-key instance (comprised of a List of keyComponentClass-objects) with the value to which it is mapped. The returned set is not backed by the OrderedSet, so a change to one (e.g., add, remove, etc.) is not reflected in the other.
        Returns:
        Entry set in composite-key order, with each entry pairing a composite-key instance (comprised of a List of keyComponentClass-objects) with the value to which it is mapped.

      • values

        public final List<V> values()
        Returns a List of the values contained in this OrderedSet, ordered according to composite-key structures stipulated by the array of KeyComponentProfiles with which the OrderedSet was constructed.
        Returns:
        values in composite-key order

      • values

        public final List<V> values(boolean suppressConsecutiveDuplicates)
        Returns a List of the values contained in this OrderedSet, ordered according to composite-key structures stipulated by the array of KeyComponentProfiles with which the OrderedSet was constructed; if the suppressConsecutiveDuplicates parameter is true, then any consecutive duplicate objects in the List will be suppressed.
        Parameters:
        suppressConsecutiveDuplicates - if true, consecutive duplicates are removed from the List before it is returned.
        Returns:
        values in composite-key order

      • values

        public final List<V> values(Object keyComponentObject)
                     throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a List of the values contained in this OrderedSet which share the submitted keyComponent-object as a common attribute; the submitted keyComponent-object must be of class equal to the keyComponentClass stipulated in the first KeyComponentProfile submitted to the constructor of this OrderedSet. The List is ordered according to composite-key structures stipulated by the array of KeyComponentProfiles with which the OrderedSet was constructed.

        For an example of effective usage of this method in conjunction with the #keyComponentSet(KeyComponentProfile) method, please see EXAMPLE 2 in the USAGE EXAMPLES.
        Parameters:
        keyComponentObject - Object of class equal to the keyComponentClass stipulated in the first KeyComponentProfile submitted to the constructor of this OrderedSet.
        Returns:
        A List of the values contained in this OrderedSet which share the submitted keyComponent-object as a common attribute.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if keyComponentObject is not of class equal to the keyComponentClass stipulated in the first KeyComponentProfile submitted to the constructor of this OrderedSet.

      • getKeyComponentProfiles

        public List<KeyComponentProfile<V>> getKeyComponentProfiles()
        Returns the list of KeyComponentProfiles with which this OrderedSet was constructed.
        Returns:
        The list of KeyComponentProfiles with which this OrderedSet was constructed.

      • keyComponentSet

        public Set<Object> keyComponentSet(KeyComponentProfile<V> keyComponentProfile)
                            throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a Set view of all keyComponentClass-objects related to the submitted KeyComponentProfile. The KeyComponentProfile must be one (or equal to one) that was submitted in the constructor of this OrderedSet.

        For example, an OrderedSet of Book-class objects constructed with a Genre|Author composite-key would maintain two separate keyComponentSets: a complete unique set of all Genre objects found in the composite-key entries, and a unique set of Author objects, as in the following example code: 
          KeyComponentProfile<Book> genreComponent
          = new KeyComponentProfile<Book>(Book.class, Genre.class);
  KeyComponentProfile<Book> authorComponent
          = new KeyComponentProfile<Book>(Book.class, Author.class);
  OrderedSet<Book> booksByGenreAndAuthor
          = new OrderedSet<Book>(myBookList, genreComponent, authorComponent);

  Set<Object> genreSet = booksByGenreAndAuthor.keyComponentSet(genreComponent);
  Set<Object> authorSet = booksByGenreAndAuthor.keyComponentSet(authorComponent);
        A keyComponentSet is a TreeSet, ordered either in natural order, hashCode order, or the order maintained by a specified Comparator. If the related keyComponentClass implements the Comparable interface, keyComponentClass-objects will be ordered in natural order; otherwise they will be ordered in hashCode order. However, if the corresponding KeyComponentProfile is constructed with specification of a Comparator, the keyComponentClass-objects will be ordered by the Comparator.
        Parameters:
        keyComponentProfile - One of the KeyComponentProfile objects that was submitted in the constructor of this OrderedSet.
        Returns:
        Set of keyComponentClass-objects related to the submitted KeyComponentProfile.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if submitted keyComponentProfile not found in this OrderedSet.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns a String showing this object's keyComponentClass structure.
        Overrides:

        A String showing this object's keyComponentClass structure.
